p: Large swath width and pixel size are unique characteristics of high temporal resolution images (e.g., AVHRR, MODIS). These sensors can frequently monitor the spread of alien plants over a broad region. However, images would capture not only the species but other components such as untargeted plants, surface soils and senescent vegetation, which would limit the ability of images for invasive plant monitoring unless one species dominates an entire system [ 40, 80]. In addition, time-series vegetation data are often contaminated by cloud and snow, and a sophisticated data smoothing algorithm may be required to filter out noise [ 81]. Large sized plots are usually required to validate the analysis, however, this would make sampling challenging on rough terrain, and the costs for time and labor are very expensive [ 46]. Moreover, background variation influenced by climate such as soil moisture dynamics could be very significant and overwrites the signals of alien plants.
